repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

body:
This is needed to replace the nvim-lspconfig function is_descendant that
some lspconfg configurations still use.

comment_data.body:
if they are both optional then we should return `true` if they are both nil.

not sure if they should be optional though. callers can opt-in to "relaxed" handling via `path or ''`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -679,4 +679,22 @@ function M.rm(path, opts)
   end
 end
 
+--- Returns `true` if `path` is relative to `root`
+--- @param path string?
+--- @param root string?
+--- @return boolean
+function M.is_relative_to(path, root)
+  if root == nil or path == nil then

comment_data.body: did we decide not to use the  absolute path or `realpath`  approach? avoids an iterator.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -679,4 +679,22 @@ function M.rm(path, opts)
   end
 end
 
+--- Returns `true` if `path` is relative to `root`
+--- @param path string?
+--- @param root string?
+--- @return boolean
+function M.is_relative_to(path, root)
+  if root == nil or path == nil then
+    return false
+  end
+  path = vim.fs.normalize(path)
+  root = vim.fs.normalize(root)
+  for dir in vim.fs.parents(path) do

comment_data.body: No strong opinions on this, string-only sounds good to me.

comment_data.body: No decision has been made, but I'm not sure it can be done in a robust way.

comment_data.body:
nit: `ok` and `ok(not ...)` look more readable. Or `assert`.
```suggestion
      ok(is_rel(p, 'a/b'))
      ok(not is_rel(p, 'c'))
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -454,4 +454,74 @@ describe('vim.fs', function()
       end)
     end)
   end)
+
+  describe('is_relative_to()', function()
+    local function is_rel(path, root)
+      return exec_lua([[return vim.fs.is_relative_to(...)]], path, root)
+    end
+    it('works', function()
+      local p = 'a/b'
+      eq(true, is_rel(p, 'a/'))
+      eq(true, is_rel(p, 'a/'))
+      eq(true, is_rel(p, 'a/b'))
+      eq(false, is_rel(p, 'c'))

comment_regular_data.body:
Chose name because it's what python calls it and you can't go wrong with doing what python does.

Will add tests once there's rough consensus we want this.

> once there's rough consensus we want this.

It's a common need, and not obvious how to do it in a reliable way.

Just for reference, what is the vimscript way to do this? chatgpt suggests:

```vim
function! IsPathRelativeTo(pathA, pathB) abort
    let l:absoluteA = fnamemodify(a:pathA, ':p')
    let l:absoluteB = fnamemodify(a:pathB, ':p')

    " Ensure pathB ends with a slash for proper comparison
    if l:absoluteB[-1] !=# '/'
        let l:absoluteB .= '/'
    endif

    return l:absoluteA[:len(l:absoluteB) - 1] ==# l:absoluteB
endfunction
```

This is good to go. I'll leave it open for a while for comments. I am alright with bikeshedding the name. On lspconfig this is called `is_descendant`, but this type of "ancestor/descendent" glossary isn't common in other language path so don't think it's particularly common.

Naming suggestion: `isrelto` or `relto` or `relativeto`

We can avoid snakecase
